title: Energy dissipated as an object rolls on a table

content.question: Read each part carefully. Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight. A group of students conducts an experiment with an object made of two uniform disks, each of radius <math alttext="R" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, and a thin axle. The disks are connected to each other with the axle at their centers and set on a horizontal table as shown in the perspective view above. The object has a mass <math alttext="uppercase M" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and total rotational inertia <math alttext="I" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>I</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> about the axis of rotation as shown. A light string is tied loosely to the axle such that the string exerts a force without wrapping around the axle. Friction between the axle and string is negligible. The string then passes over an ideal pulley and is tied to a block of mass <math alttext="lowercase m equals 1.0 kilogram" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>m</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1.0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>kg</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. At time <math alttext="t equals 0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> the object-block system is released from rest, and the block accelerates downward. In this case, the object rolls without slipping on the table. The coefficients of static and kinetic friction between the object and table are <math alttext="mu sub s" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>μ</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>s</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="mu sub k" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>μ</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>k</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, respectively. (a) Point P is marked on the pulley, as shown in the side view above. State the direction of the velocity and acceleration of point P when the pulley has completed one full rotation and point P has returned to its initial position. Explain your reasoning.

The graphs above show the downward linear acceleration of the block and the angular acceleration of the object as a function of the mass of the block. (b) When the mass of the block is large enough, the object slips as it rolls forward. What is the minimum mass of the block that causes the object to slip? Reference appropriate features of the graphs to support your answer citing relevant physics principles.
